title: Harvey Norman's $174m capital raise falls short
text:
Harvey Norman's $174 million capital raising has fallen $7.8 million short, even though the new shares were issued at a discount of as much as 46 per cent to the market price.

Harvey Norman executive chairman Gerry Harvey and other directors are set to marginally increase their stakes after an $8 million shortfall in the retailer's latest capital raising. Nic Walker

The one for 17 renounceable entitlement offer closed last Friday, and Harvey Norman shareholders applied to buy 66.3 million of the 69.4 million shares offered at $2.50 a share, leaving a shortfall of 3.1 million shares worth $7.8 million.

Harvey Norman shares fell 1.5 per cent to $3.81 in early trade on Wednesday, when the shortfall was announced, but traded as high as $4.63 during the offer period.

The shortfall means executive chairman Gerry Harvey, who owns 31.3 per cent, chief executive Katie Page and other directors, who took up their full entitlements, are set to marginally increase the size of their stakes.

Shareholder activist Stephen Mayne, who is attempting to get a seat on the Harvey Norman board at the annual meeting next month, offered to withdraw his nomination if Harvey Norman agreed to compensate shareholders who did not take up their rights by auctioning off the shortfall to the highest bidder in an institutional book build.
